summary: This is a letter from attorney Patrick J. Smith to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the Ghislaine Maxwell case. It informs the court of a third production of documents responsive to Maxwell's subpoena, specifically claim packets and communications related to four individuals, posted to a secure FTP site.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The presiding judge in the Southern District of New York to whom the letter is addressed regarding the document production in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Patrick J. Smith
persons.role: Attorney for the independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program
persons.context: The author of the letter, representing the non-party administrator and coordinating the production of documents in response to Maxwell's subpoena.

events.title: Court's memo-endorsement of letter
events.description: The court endorsed a prior letter from Smith Villazor LLP, referenced as the basis for the current document production.

events.title: Court order regarding FTP site
events.description: The court issued an order indicating that posting documents to a secure FTP site was a sufficient means of production.

events.title: Third document production to court
events.description: Patrick J. Smith's firm makes a third production of documents (claim packets and attorney communications) to the court in response to Maxwell's subpoena.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007

keyFacts: This document is part of the discovery process in United States v. Maxwell, case number 20 Cr. 330.
The independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program is producing documents in response to a subpoena from defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.
The production includes claim packets and email communications with attorneys for four specific individuals identified in the subpoena.
Documents have been redacted per Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 49.1(a) and to protect the identities of other claimants.
The documents were delivered via a secure FTP site, with credentials previously provided to the court.
